Title:
Control of damping-off in tomato seedlings exerted by isolate
ILBB 145 of Serratia ureilytica
Abstract:
Serratia ureilytica is a species closely related to S.
marcescens not yet reported from diseased patients, suitable to be
explored as a plant growth promoting bacteria (PGPB). In horticulture,
the production of healthy and vigorous tomato seedlings is a key step in
the process leading to the establishment of productive tomato plant
stands, able to bear fruit of high quality. Production of seedlings
usually takes place in greenhouses to reduce the impact of varying
weather conditions. However, excessive humidity, slow seedling emergence
and soil-dwelling pathogens like Pythium spp. can lead to losses by
damping-off. In this work, we describe the biocontrol and plant growth
promotion activity of strain ILBB 145 of S. ureilytica, characterize the
phenotypic traits that could help explain the observed activities, and
explore its genome in relation with genomes of two other strains of S.
ureilytica and S. marcescens to further account for genetic determinants
of pathogenicity and antimicrobial resistance that could hamper its use
as PGPB.
